description.cancellation_policy:
Change Policy:

  • A permit authorizes the trip leader to enter a specific river segment on a specific date. Once reserved, the entry date, entry segment, trip leader and alternates may not be changed. 
  • Before printing your permit or at the launch point, you may change your:
    • group size
    • # of boats
    • take-out & date
    • Launch point if within segment 3B
  • The trip leader is required to tear off the bottom of the printed permit and deposit it in the box at the launch kiosk. Mark allowed changes. 

Cancellation Policy:

  • Failure to cancel your permit or to register your party at the launch kiosk will trigger a “No Show” status.
  • See no show policies. 
  • If you cannot make a trip, you must cancel your permit on Recreation.gov. Cancel ASAP to allow other boaters to use your space. Follow instructions under your existing reservations.
  • If the permit is already printed, you must email or call the BLM (blm_John_day_river@blm.gov, 541-416-6700) to cancel.
description.description:
The John Day River is one of the longest free-flowing rivers in the continental United States and offers a range of recreational opportunities including boating, fishing, and leave no trace camping.        

An online permit is required year-round for both day and overnight boating trips within the Wild and Scenic section of the John Day River (Service Creek to Tumwater Falls) and is only available here on Recreation.gov.  

See the Segment Map and Descriptions along with the High Season Release Schedule for details.  

One permit covers an entire group for the length of the trip and is based on launch date and launch segment. Launch date and launch segment cannot be changed.

 LOW SEASON

  • Choose low season in the drop down menu regardless of river segment
  • For Sep 1 - Nov 30 choose fall low season except Segment 1trips

HIGH SEASON

You do not need a separate permit per segment. You may takeout at any boat ramp downstream of your launch point even if you float into other segments. Exceptions: Segment 3 and Long Distance (see segment descriptions below).  

  • Segment 3
    • 3A: Entering the Wild and Scenic section at Service Creek (includes launching upstream of Service Creek) 
    • 3B: Launching at Twickenham, Priest Hole, or Lower Burnt Ranch    
    • Segment 3A and 3B permits do not allow parties to takeout downstream of Clarno during High Season
  • Segment 2A: Launching at Clarno
  • Segment 2B: Launching at Thirtymile 
  • Segment 1A: Launching at Cottonwood Bridge (Burres)
  • Segment 1B: Launching at Starvation Lane, Rock Creek, or John Day Crossing (McDonald)  
  • Long Distance Permits (New Category for High Season)  
    • This permit is for parties who want to launch in Segment 3 and float past Clarno. If you want to takeout at Clarno, a Segment 3 permit is the correct option. Clarno to Cottonwood is not long distance; it is 2A.
    • For High Season launch dates, the Long Distance category will show in the drop down menu. Put in options will be available for all Segment 3 boat launches. Takeout options will not allow for Clarno but will be available for all boat ramps downstream of Clarno.   

If you are launching in Segment 3 the last week of April and want to float past Clarno, you will also need a High Season permit for Segment 2 (unless you are below Clarno on April 30). We recommend limiting layovers during this transition period.

 

*Trip leaders are required to register at the boat launch. Print the permit and leave the bottom registration section of the permit in the box at the launch kiosk, or hand it to agency personnel if present. Carry the rest of the permit on the river in an accessible location.   

 

Whitewater boating skills are necessary to navigate all sections of the river. Water levels fluctuate greatly.

May through early July usually have the best flows. See the minimum water level recommendations per craft , Current water levels , along with short term and long term water level forecasts. A resource for flows and descriptions is American whitewater . 

Visit our John Day River website for more information.
description.driving_directions:
Service Creek Boat Launch

From Prineville, Oregon, take US 26 east out of town and drive 46.5 miles to OR 207 N. Turn left and drive 23.5 miles. Service Creek Campground and boat launch will be on the right.

Clarno Boat Launch 

From Prineville, Oregon, take US 26 north out of town and drive 30 miles to US 97. Turn right and stay on US 97 for 19.5 miles. Turn right on OR 293 and proceed 13.6 miles to OR218 and turn right continuing another 15 miles to the Clarno Recreation Site and boat launch on the left (north) side of the highway. 

Thirtymile Boat Launch

See Thirymile/Armstrong Road Visitor Information and seasonal closure information.
description.fee_policy:
Reservation Fee:

A $6.00 non-refundable reservation fee is required for each permit issued. Only one permit is needed per boating group. Each member of a group must remain with the trip leader while on the river.

Recreation Fee:

A non-refundable recreation fee is due when a reservation is made for trips entering the Wild and Scenic section during the High Season (between Service Creek and Tumwater Falls from May 1- July 15, and between Cottonwood Canyon and Tumwater Falls from Sep 1- Nov 30).  

The recreation fee is $20 per overnight trip per group, or $10 per one-day trip per group. All recreation fees are used directly on the river to help keep launch sites and river campsites clean.
description.need_to_know_email:
This is NOT your permit.

Printing your Permit

  • You can print your permit within 14 days of your launch date, by signing into your Recreation.gov account.  
  • You must print, sign and bring your permit with you on your trip. 
  • The permit is valid only for the launch segment and launch date for which it is issued.  
  • Once reserved, the launch segment, launch date, trip leader and alternates may not be changed. 
  • Permit fees are non-refundable.

Launch Registration is Required

  • Boaters are required to complete the Boater Registration form at the bottom of the printed permit and deposit the form in the boater registration box at the launch. Keep the top part of the permit with you at all times. 

Allowable Changes

  • Before you print your permit or when you submit your Boater Registration form at the launch point, you may change your: 
    • group size
    • launch point if within segment 3B
    • take-out point
    • take-out date

Cancellation Policy

  • If you cannot make this trip, you must cancel your permit. You should cancel your permit as soon as your plans change, but no later than the day before your trip, to allow another boater to use your space and to avoid being flagged as a “No Show.” No show permit holders will be put on a restricted list and will not be able to get a John Day Permit for 2 years.
  • If you have not printed your permit, you may cancel it online at Recreation.gov. Go to your current reservation and follow the instructions. If you have already printed your permit, call the BLM at 541-416-6700 to cancel your permit.

Helpful River Information

  • Click here for detailed river information, including recommended flows per craft and links to current water levels.
  • Since you paid a fee for this permit, you do not need an Oregon Waterway Access Permit for this trip on the John Day River. See the Oregon State Marine Board website for further information.
  • For information about Thirtymile Launch see Thirtymile/Armstrong Road Visitor Information
description.need_to_know_order:
When reserving a permit on this river, I understand that:

  • A permit is issued to enter a specific river segment on a specific date, and once reserved, the entry date and entry segment cannot be changed; 
  • Permit fees are non-refundable;
  • One launch permit is needed per group and the maximum group size is 16 persons, except on Segment 1A and 1B in the Fall, when the maximum group size is 4 people;
  • The Trip Leader or Alternate is required to be present on the entire trip and may be requested to show the permit and photo ID during the trip.
  • As Trip Leader, I am responsible for the actions of my group;
  • As Trip Leader, I be at least 13 years old before the launch date;
  • I may hold a maximum of one overnight permit and three day-use permits at one time;
  • My group must carry out our solid human and pet waste in an approved portable toilet system;
  • No wood or charcoal fires are allowed from June 1-September 30, and when allowed, fires must be contained in a metal firepan and all ashes carried out of the river canyon; and 
  • This reservation/application is for a private (non-commercial) trip unless I am authorized by the Bureau of Land Management to be a commercial outfitter on this river.
description.need_to_know_permit:
When reserving a permit on this river, I understand that:

  • The permit is valid only for the entry date and entry segment for which it is issued;  
  • After a reservation is made, the entry date, entry segment and trip leader may not be changed and alternate trip leaders may not be added;
  • Permit fees are non-refundable;
  • The maximum group size is 16 people and groups may not combine at any time if this number would be exceeded. In Segment 1A and 1B in the Fall (September 1-November 30), the group size is 4 people;
  • I must print, sign, and carry my permit on the river, leaving the bottom boater registration portion in the box at the launch kiosk. Permits may be printed up to 14 days before the launch date on Recreation.gov;
  • The Trip Leader or Alternate is required to be present on the entire trip and may be requested to show the permit and a photo ID during the trip;
  • As Trip Leader, I am responsible for the actions of my group;
  • As Trip Leader, I will be at least 13 years old before the launch date;
  • I may hold a maximum of one overnight permit and three day-use permits at one time;
  • My group must carry out our solid human waste in an approved portable toilet system ;
  • No wood or charcoal fires are allowed from June 1-September 30. When allowed, fires must be contained in a metal firepan and all ashes carried out; 
  • This reservation/application is for a private (non-commercial) trip unless I am authorized to be a commercial outfitter on this river.

Annual Fire Closure

  • The John Day River is closed to all campfires, charcoal fires and propane campfire devices from June 1-September 30 each year. 
  • Propane and white gas cooking stoves and shielded lanterns are permitted. 
  • Smoking is permitted only in a closed vehicle, while standing in the water, or while in a boat on the water.
  • Using or possessing fireworks is prohibited.

Fires in Firepans Only

  • When fires are allowed, ground fires and rock fire rings are not permitted. Watch for dry vegetation . 
  • Fires and ash must be completely contained in an elevated metal firepan with sides at least two inches high. 
  • Burn wood from home, charcoal, driftwood, or dead and down vegetation. Standing vegetation, either dead or alive, may not be cut or gathered. 
  • All campfire residue must be carried out of the canyon.

Portable Toilet Requirement

  • On overnight and day trips, all boating groups are required to carry and use a water-tight, reusable toilet system large enough to service the entire party for the complete length of the trip.
  • All buckets used to carry human waste are required to have a rubber gasket in the lid. 
  • Dump stations are not available at takeouts. See the list of rv dumpstations . 
  • Plastic bags are not allowed, except human waste bags specifically designed for this purpose.  
  • Dispose of used human waste bags in a garbage dumpster. Disposing of bags in a vault toilet is strictly prohibited.

Pack It In, Pack It Out

  • Carry out all garbage, including cigarette butts, toilet paper and organics. 
  • Pack out food scraps to keep critters to a minimum. 
  • Do not bury trash or toilet paper; animals may dig it up
  • Strain all dish/wastewater through a screen to remove food particles, and pack them out. 
  • Scatter wastewater over a wide area, away from campsites, at least 200 ft. from the river. 
  • Soap should be used sparingly, as even biodegradable varieties are slow to break down.
  • At flows above 500 cfs, urinate in the river.
  • At flows below 500 cfs, urinate at least 200 ft. away from camp.
  • Ensure all boats are clean, drained and dry prior to launch.

Motorized Boating

  • Clarno to Cottonwood is closed to motorized boats year-round. From Cottonwood Bridge downstream, the river is closed to motorized boats from May 1 - September 30. Between Service Creek and Clarno, the river is restricted to electric motors from May 1 - September 30.
  • There are no motorized boat restrictions upstream of Service Creek.
  • The river is closed to personal watercraft (jet skis) year-round upstream of Tumwater Falls.
  • See Motorized Boating for more information.
description.no_show_policy:
Boater Registration is required.  

  • To register your trip, tear off the Boater Registration form, which is the bottom part of your printed permit. Mark any allowable changes to the permit details, and deposit the form in the boater registration box at any launch point kiosk.
  • If you fail to submit your Boater Registration and you did not cancel your permit, you will be flagged as a “No Show.”

“No Show” permit leaders will be added to a restricted list and will not be able to reserve another John Day River permit for two years. We are implementing this no show penalty to encourage those who can't make the trip to cancel their reservation, making that slot available for someone else to book. Please be mindful of your fellow boaters and cancel your permit as soon as you know you cannot take the trip. It could be your party one day waiting for a cancellation.
description.quota_details:
Quota for Overnight High Season permits is measured in the number of boating groups entering the Wild and Scenic River (Service Creek to Tumwater Falls) per day. One permit covers an entire group. 

Low Season quota: Unlimited  

High Season quota (total groups per day): 

50% of the following quota (rounded up to a whole number) will be released 4 months in advance of a given launch date. The remaining 50% will be released 1 month in advance. See Quota and High Season Release Schedule . 

  • Segment 3A: 8 
  • Segment 3B: 9 
  • Segment 2A: 5 
  • Segment 2B: 4 
  • Segment 1A: 4; 2 in the Fall 
  • Segment 1B: 2; 1 in the Fall 
  • Long Distance Permits (High Season only): 2 

Stay limit is 14 days.

Groups may have no more than 16 people. Group limits are put in place to help protect the resource and for solitude. Please pay respect to other boaters and to the river by remaining within these limits. 

See Boater Etiquette    

Segments 1A & 1B:

  • Group size limit is 4 from Sep. 1 - Nov. 30
  • Stay limit is 1 night per segment year round
description.season_information:
This permit is for an Overnight boating trip. For Day Use permits click here.  

Permits are unlimited except during High Season which is from:

  • Service Creek to Tumwater Falls (May 1-July 15)
  • Cottonwood Bridge (Burres) to Tumwater Falls (September 1-November 30)  

Daily Rolling Release: High Season permits are first-come first-served and become available on Recreation.gov at 7am Pacific Time 4 months and 1 month in advance of a given launch date. See the High Season Release Schedule .     

You cannot print your permit more than 14 days before your trip. Prior to printing your permit, you can cancel directly on Recreation.gov. Once printed, you must email or call the BLM to cancel. Cancelled permits return to the Recreation.gov availability calendar. See Fees/Cancellations.

Trip leaders or alternates must be present the entire trip. Add alternate trip leaders when first obtaining your permit, they cannot be added later. You can be a trip leader or alternate on 1 overnight permit at a time.
description.tertiary_page:
Safety: Many sections of the John Day River are remote with limited to no emergency access or cell service. Depending on water level and section of river, you may encounter Class lll to lV rapids. Wind and weather can be extreme and the water can be cold. Don't be scared, just come prepared! See the recommended safety equipment under boater safety.

Private Property: The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. Use a map and gps to ensure your location, and please respect private property. S1 mobil mapper is a great map ap showing land ownership and location even when out of cell range.     

Waterway Access Permit Exemption: On the John Day River, an Oregon Waterway Access Permit is not required during High Season from Service Creek to Tumwater Falls but is required during Low Season. For more information, please visit the Oregon State Marine Board website.  

Invasive Species: Please help lessen the spread of invasive species by limiting travel through infested areas and by cleaning and drying watercraft. Inspect clothing, gear, and watercraft for aquatic and terrestrial invasives.    

RIVER SEGMENT DESCRIPTIONS: 

All boat ramps are primitive.  

See launch and camping information for further detail.

Segment 3A and 3B:

  • Segment 3A includes the 13 miles stretch between Service Creek and Twickenham. 
  • Segment 3B is the 35 mile section between Twickenham and Clarno.
  • With several access points, a variety of scenic or bass fishing trips can be enjoyed. Twickenham to Priest Hole has the least whitewater. A popular overnight float is the 48-mile section from Service Creek to Clarno.
  •  Priest Hole and Burnt Ranch access is via remote, gravel roads. 4x4 is recommended for Burnt Ranch. 
  • Twickenham is private land available for public boat access via an Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife easement. Please observe all posted regulations and pick up all garbage to help ensure good relations. 
  • Car camping is available at Service Creek (walk-in), Priest Hole (dispersed) and Lower Burnt Ranch (4 picnic tables and fire rings- 4x4 recommended). No drinking water is available at these sites.

Keep the following rapids in mind:  

Russo, Class II (River Mile 150.2) 

Tap Horn, Class II (River Mile 149.2)

Burnt Ranch, Class II+ (River Mile 132.4) - watch for low flows!  

SEGMENT 2A AND 2B

  • Segment 2A is the 25-mile section between Clarno and Thirtymile and has the most whitewater of any section.
    • Whitewater experience and craft appropriate for the water level are a necessity. See recommended flows per craft under water flow.
    • Watch out for Clarno Rapid which can be big at high flows and an impassable boulder garden at low flows (Class III-IV, RM 104.8, Scout left) 
    • Basalt Rapid, Class II-III (RM 93) can be challenging, especially in a canoe or drift boat. Scouting is advised. 
    • The canyon is scenic and passes through the North Pole Ridge and Thirtymile Wilderness Study Areas.  
  • Segment 2B is the 44-mile section between Thirtymile and J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge). 
    • Whitewater is scarce, the scenery is impressive, and bighorn sheep can usually be seen scrambling over the rocky slopes. Low flows can be challenging and slow. 
    • You’ll float through the Thirtymile and Lower John Day Wilderness Study Areas, managed for a primitive recreation experience.  
  • Thirtymile is 4x4 highly recommended and has a seasonal closure from Dec 1- April 15th each year.  
  • Car camping exists at Thirtymile (dispersed, no water) and Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers, cabins).  

SEGMENT 1A AND 1B

  • Segment 1A is the 10-mile section between J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) and Starvation Lane, floating through Cottonwood Canyon State Park.
  • Segment 1B is the 19-mile section between Starvation Lane and Tumwater Falls. 
  • Starvation Lane is 4x4 recommended. Access at Starvation Lane is sometimes closed when water flows drop below 200 cfs or the roads are too muddy. Please check conditions with Cottonwood Canyon State Park .
  • McDonald Crossing (RM 21) is the last public take-out before Tumwater Falls (RM 10). Be sure to takeout at the crossing itself as the John Day Crossing Historic site (just downstream with parking and a toilet) is not a feasible takeout unless you plan to hand carry. 
  • Rock Creek access is steep and is also only suitable for hand carrying. 
  • Mcdonald Crossing and Rock Creek can be hard to navigate to. Mapping aps may send you to locked gates on private land. Make sure you have a paper map or atlas with you as cell service does not exist as of November 2021.
  • Car Camping: Camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers, cabins). Dispersed camping is available at the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site (toilet and picnic tables) and at Rock Creek (suitable only for 1-2 small parties, picnic table and fire ring) on the east side of the river. No drinking water is available at these sites.

755.description:
This permit is to launch at Service Creek or to enter the Wild and Scenic section at Service Creek from boating upstream.

Segment 3A is the 13-mile section between Service Creek and Twickenham. This segment Is usually run as a day trip or as part of the 48-mile run from Service Creek to Clarno. Flowing through a rugged desert landscape dotted with sagebrush and juniper, this segment is a good place to enjoy bass fishing or a trip with family and friends. You’ll encounter a series of long gentle pools, riffles and bends in the river. But don’t get too relaxed, as there are two Class II rapids to contend with that can easily swamp a canoe.

  • Avoid the crowds In Segment 3A by staying away from Friday launches from May 15 -July 3.

description_map.need_to_know:
• The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • Boat-in campsites are few; try to camp early.
  • Twickenham is private land available for public boat access via an Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife easement. Please observe all posted regulations.
    • .
  • Russo Rapid, Class II (River Mile 150.2) can push a boat into the rock wall on river left at 3,000+ cfs.
  • Tap Horn Rapid, Class II (River Mile 149.2) in a hard-shell boat requires careful maneuvering to avoid hitting rocks at 1,200 cfs or less.
  • Both rapids produce standing waves that can swamp a canoe at 2,500+ cfs.
  • Car Camping: Service Creek (walk-in) and Muleshoe. No drinking water is available.

755.name: 3A (Restricted Takeouts)

756.description:
This permit is to launch at Twickenham, Priest Hole or Lower Burnt Ranch.

Segment 3B is the 35-mile section between Twickenham and Clarno, with several access points. A variety of day and overnight trips are possible. You’ll float past rugged canyon walls and colorful ash layers, amid a backdrop of sweeping volcanic vistas. Where the canyon widens, you’ll pass a few agricultural fields before it narrows again. Depending on your route, you may encounter Class II+ Burnt Ranch Rapid (River Mile 132.4), which can be avoided by launching at Lower Burnt Ranch. Generally, this segment has less gradient making for slower (good fishing) water.

  • Avoid the crowds in Segment 3B by staying away from Friday launches at Twickenham from May 15-July 3.

description_map.need_to_know:
• Twickenham is on private land available for public boat access via an Oregon Department of Fish & Wildlife easement. Please observe all posted regulations.
  • A 4x4 vehicle is recommended for boat ramp access at Lower Burnt Ranch.
  • Burnt Ranch Rapid, Class II+ (River mile 132.4) has large boulders that create powerful hydraulics at higher flows and unavoidable hazards at low flows. When in doubt, scout.
  • The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • Planning Tip: Winds frequently blow upstream in the afternoon; please plan accordingly.
  • Car Camping: Dispersed camping is available at Priest Hole (no drinking water).

756.name: 3B (Restricted Takeouts)

757.description:
This permit is to launch at Clarno.

Segment 2A is the 25-mile section between Clarno and Thirtymile. Boaters will encounter Clarno Rapid (Class III-IV) approximately 5 miles downstream of the launch point. Whitewater experience and watercraft appropriate for the water level are a necessity. Starting as a wide braided river channel, the canyon quickly constricts at Clarno Rapid, then widens again. You’ll pass some rural fields and buildings before seeming to leave all development behind as you enter the scenic landscapes of the North Pole Ridge and Thirtymile Wilderness Study Areas.

  • Avoid the crowds at Clarno by launching on a Tuesday or Saturday.

description_map.need_to_know:
• A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Thirtymile.
  • Clarno Rapid, Class III-IV (RM 104.8-104.2, Scout left) is a boulder garden at low flows, impassable for heavy rafts and drift boats. Spring floods can turn it into a raging torrent of whitewater. If you flip your boat and lose your gear, you face a 5-mile hike back to Clarno Bridge.
  • Basalt Rapid, Class II-III (RM 93) can be challenging, especially in a canoe or drift boat. Scouting is advised.
  • The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • Planning Tip: Winds frequently blow upstream in the afternoon; plan accordingly.
  • Car Camping: Dispersed camping is available at Thirtymile (no drinking water).

757.name: 2A

758.description:
This permit is to launch at Thirtymile.

Segment 2B is the 44-mile section between Thirtymile and J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge). Here, the river carves a deep, twisted canyon and interesting geologic features abound. Whitewater is scarce, the scenery is impressive, and bighorn sheep can usually be seen scrambling over the rocky slopes. You’ll float through the Thirtymile and Lower John Day Wilderness Study Areas, which the BLM manages for a primitive recreation experience. At low water levels, braided channels test water-reading skills, as choosing the ‘wrong’ channel can mean dragging your boat over a gravel bar.

  • Avoid the crowds at Thirtymile by staying away from Thursday and Friday launches from May 15-July 3.

description_map.need_to_know:
• A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Thirtymile.
  • The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • Planning Tip: Winds frequently blow upstream in the afternoon; please plan accordingly.
  • Car Camping: Dispersed camping is available at Thirtymile (no drinking water); developed camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers, etc.).

758.name: 2B

759.description:
This permit is to launch at JS Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) from May 1-July 15.

Segment 1A is the 10-mile section between J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) and Starvation Lane. Here, you’ll float through Cottonwood Canyon State Park, where the river channel is wide, and the views are even wider. At low water levels, braided channels test water-reading skills, as choosing the ‘wrong’ channel can mean dragging your boat over a gravel bar. Boaters must camp in signed, designated boat-in campsites, and camping is limited to one night in Segment 1A and one night in Segment 1B.

description_map.need_to_know:
• The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • In Segments 1A and 1B, boaters must camp in signed designated boat-in campsites as shown on map. Camping limit is 1 night per segment.
  • A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Starvation Lane.
  • Boating access at Starvation Lane is temporarily closed each summer/fall whenever water flows drop below 200 cfs.
  • McDonald Crossing (RM 21) is the last public take-out before Tumwater Falls (RM 10).
  • Car Camping: Developed camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers). Dispersed camping is available at the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site on the east side of the river (no drinking water).

759.name: 1A

760.description:
This permit is to launch at Starvation Lane, Rock Creek or McDonald Crossing from May 1-July 15.

Segment 1B is the 19-mile section between Starvation Lane and Tumwater Falls. If you are after solitude, you will likely find it here. Most of the land along the riverbanks is privately owned, and the shore tends to be rocky, making campsite options extremely limited. If you plan to take out at Rock Creek, be prepared for a boat carry, otherwise continue to the last take-out at McDonald Crossing, which can be accessed by road from the east side of the river. At the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site (east side), look for tracks left by immigrants traveling the Oregon Trail (1840-1860) as they crossed the river and continued west.

description_map.need_to_know:
• The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • In Segments 1A and 1B, boaters must camp in signed designated boat-in campsites as shown on map. Camping limit is 1 night per segment.
  • A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Starvation Lane.
  • Boating access at Starvation Lane is temporarily closed each summer/fall whenever water flows drop below 200 cfs.
  • McDonald Crossing (RM 21) is the last public take-out before Tumwater Falls (RM 10).
  • Car Camping: Developed camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers). Dispersed camping is available at the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site on the east side of the river (no drinking water).

760.name: 1B

761.description:
This permit is to launch at J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) in the fall from September 1-November 30.

Segment 1A is the 10-mile section between J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) and Starvation Lane. Here, you’ll float through Cottonwood Canyon State Park, where the river channel is wide, and the views are even wider. In the fall, hunters access deer and upland bird habitat and anglers come seeking steelhead. Negotiating braided channels at low water flows can mean dragging your boat over a gravel bar. Boaters must camp in signed, designated boat-in campsites, and camping is limited to one night each in Segment 1A and Segment 1B.

description_map.need_to_know:
• The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • In Segments 1A and 1B, boaters must camp in signed designated boat-in campsites as shown on map. Camping limit is 1 night per segment.
  • A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Starvation Lane.
  • Boating access at Starvation Lane is temporarily closed each summer/fall whenever water flows drop below 200 cfs.
  • McDonald Crossing (RM 21) is the last public take-out before Tumwater Falls (RM 10).
  • Car Camping: Developed camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers). Dispersed camping is available at the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site on the east side of the river (no drinking water).

761.name: Low Season

762.description:
This permit is to launch at Starvation Lane, Rock Creek or McDonald Crossing from September 1-November 30.

Segment 1B is the 19-mile section between Starvation Lane and Tumwater Falls. If you are after solitude, you will likely find it here. Most of the land along the riverbanks is privately owned, and the shore tends to be rocky, making campsite options extremely limited. If you plan to take out at Rock Creek, be prepared for a boat carry, otherwise continue to the last take-out at McDonald Crossing, which can be accessed by road from the east side of the river. At the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site (east side) look for tracks left by immigrants traveling the Oregon Trail (1840-1860) as they crossed the river and continued west.

description_map.need_to_know:
• The river flows through a mix of public and private lands. You may only camp or hike on public land. Use a map/gps to track your location.
  • In Segments 1A and 1B, boaters must camp in signed designated boat-in campsites as shown on map. Camping limit is 1 night per segment.
  • A 4x4 vehicle is recommended at Starvation Lane.
  • Boating access at Starvation Lane is temporarily closed each summer/fall whenever water flows drop below 200 cfs.
  • McDonald Crossing (RM 21) is the last public take-out before Tumwater Falls (RM 10).
  • Car Camping: Developed camping is available at Cottonwood Canyon State Park (water, showers). Dispersed camping is available at the BLM John Day Crossing Recreation Site on the east side of the river (no drinking water).

762.name: Fall Low Season (Service Creek to Cottonwood)

important_dates.description: Spring High Season between Service Creek and Tumwater Falls
Fall High Season between J.S. Burres (Cottonwood Bridge) and Tumwater Falls
Daily rolling release allows 50% of permits to become available for reservation 4 months prior to a given launch date at 7am PT. See the High Season Release Schedule.
Daily rolling release allows remaining 50% of permits to become available for reservation 1 month prior to a given launch date at 7am PT
Thirtymile Boat Launch is not accessible by vehicle from Dec 1 - April 15 during the winter closure of Armstrong Canyon Rd.
